title: Quiz 4: NCK Paper One - January 2009
description: Licensure Examination covering General Nursing, Pharmacology, and Medical-Surgical Nursing (January 2009).

questions.question: The major factors associated with obesity include:
questions.explanation: Obesity is primarily driven by an energy imbalance (nutrition vs. activity) but is strongly influenced by genetic predisposition.
questions.hint: Think about the 'Big 3' physiological determinants: Genes, Food, Movement.

questions.question: During assessment of hearing, the Rinne test is used to:

options.text: Evaluate the patient’s ability to hear high frequency sounds
Compare bone conduction with air conduction in both ears
Determine the degree of hearing loss

questions.explanation: The Rinne test compares Air Conduction (AC) to Bone Conduction (BC) to distinguish between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.hint: This test involves moving the tuning fork from the mastoid bone to the ear canal.

questions.question: A synergistic interaction between furosemide and gentamicin may cause:
questions.explanation: Both Loop Diuretics (Furosemide) and Aminoglycosides (Gentamicin) have ototoxicity as a major side effect. Using them together significantly increases the risk of hearing damage.
questions.hint: Both drugs can damage the cranial nerve VIII (Vestibulocochlear).

questions.question: In the elderly, peptic ulceration induced by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can best be treated/prevented with:
questions.explanation: NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandins which protect the stomach lining. Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog that replenishes this protection.
questions.hint: This drug replaces the protective substance that NSAIDs remove.

questions.question: Temper tantrums are common in:
questions.explanation: Temper tantrums are a developmental norm for toddlers (1-3 years) due to the frustration of seeking autonomy without having adequate language skills.
questions.hint: The 'Terrible Twos' occur in this age group.

questions.question: Hordeolum externum (sty) is an infection of the:

options.text: Tarsal glands (or glands of Zeis/Moll) of the eyelid

questions.explanation: A sty is an acute infection of the glands at the base of the eyelashes (Zeis/Moll) or within the eyelid (Meibomian/Tarsal glands).
questions.hint: It appears as a red, painful lump on the edge of the eyelid.

questions.question: Pelvic Inflammatory Diseases (PID) include:
questions.explanation: PID is an upper reproductive tract infection involving the Cervix, Uterus (Endometrium), Fallopian Tubes (Salpinx), and Ovaries (Oophor). Candidiasis and Trichomoniasis are lower tract infections.
questions.hint: Look for inflammation of the upper reproductive organs (uterus, tubes, ovaries).

questions.question: A clinical path (critical pathway) is defined as:

options.text: Day to day activities that will be carried out for a particular patient
An outline of steps a patient will take from admission to discharge
A predetermined outline of patient care for a specific episode of care
A predetermined outline of medical and surgical care procedures for a specific episode of care

questions.explanation: Clinical paths are multidisciplinary plans that outline the optimal sequencing and timing of interventions for a particular diagnosis or procedure to ensure quality and efficiency.
questions.hint: It is a standardized plan/schedule of care.

questions.question: Cholelithiasis is primarily associated with:

options.text: Abnormal metabolism of cholesterol and bile salts
Abnormal metabolism of lipids and bile acids

questions.explanation: Gallstones form when bile is supersaturated with cholesterol or has insufficient bile salts to keep it soluble.
questions.hint: Most gallstones are made of hardened cholesterol.

questions.question: Increased tactile fremitus may occur in:
questions.explanation: Tactile fremitus (vibration) is increased when sound travels through solid/consolidated tissue (Pneumonia) and decreased when blocked by air or fluid.
questions.hint: Sound travels better through solids (consolidation) than air.

questions.question: Atopic dermatitis commonly develops in individuals aged:
questions.explanation: Infantile eczema (atopic dermatitis) typically begins early in life, often between 2 and 6 months of age.
questions.hint: It is very common in infants.

questions.question: Chvostek’s sign is used for the diagnosis of:
questions.explanation: Chvostek's sign (facial twitching) indicates neuromuscular irritability caused by low calcium levels (hypocalcemia), often due to low parathyroid hormone.
questions.hint: Think 'Low Calcium' and the gland that regulates it.

questions.question: Glomerulonephritis usually follows infection with:
questions.explanation: Acute Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis typically occurs 1-3 weeks after a Group A Beta-hemolytic streptococcal infection (throat or skin).
questions.hint: It often follows a sore throat or impetigo.

questions.question: Which statement characterizes Prinzmetal’s Angina (Variant Angina)?

options.text: Occurs with known amount of activity, density of pain remain stable
Occurs with increasing severity, pain is unpredictable
Occurs same time each day, caused by coronary artery spasms
Always occur due to atherosclerotic lesion, pain increases with activity

questions.explanation: Prinzmetal's angina is caused by vasospasm, occurs at rest (often at night/early morning), and is often cyclic.
questions.hint: It is caused by spasms, not blockage, and often happens while resting.

questions.question: The teeth that commonly get impacted are the:
questions.explanation: Wisdom teeth (3rd molars) are the last to erupt and often lack space, leading to impaction.
questions.hint: The last teeth to come in.

questions.question: Body mechanics prescribed for clients with low back pain include:

options.text: Bending at knee and hips, keeping objects close to the body
Bending at the waist while keeping legs straight
Carrying objects far from the body

questions.explanation: Proper lifting involves using the legs (knees/hips) rather than the back and keeping the load's center of gravity close to the body.
questions.hint: Lift with your legs, not your back.

questions.question: The type of immunoglobulins involved in Type III immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity are:
questions.explanation: Type III hypersensitivity involves IgG and IgM antibodies forming complexes with antigens that deposit in tissues.
questions.hint: These are the most abundant antibodies in the blood.

questions.question: The major nursing interventions for a patient with hemolytic anemia focus on:

options.text: Protection from injury and understanding the condition
Reduced stress and absence of infection
Protection from injury and prevention of infection

questions.explanation: Hemolytic anemia patients are prone to fatigue (injury risk) and may be immunocompromised due to spleen dysfunction or treatment (infection risk).
questions.hint: Safety and infection control are priorities.

questions.question: During the pre-operative period, drugs used to achieve sedation, reduce anxiety, and cause amnesia include:
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines (Midazolam, Diazepam) are the class of drugs specifically used for sedation, anxiolysis, and anterograde amnesia.
questions.hint: Think of the drug class ending in -lam or -pam.

questions.question: When monitoring a patient for a suspected Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) leak, which findings should the nurse observe for? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Signs of CSF leak include clear drainage from nose/ears, the Halo sign (blood spot surrounded by clear ring), and presence of glucose in the fluid.
questions.hint: Look for signs of fluid leaking from the skull and ways to distinguish it from mucus.
